articles.headline: In Finance, Japan Sees an Opening
articles.snippet: As the global financial order convulses, some Japanese leaders believe the country should take a more active role in economic leadership.
articles.abstract: As the global financial order convulses, some Japanese leaders believe the country should take a more active role in economic leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Just six months ago, five or six “bulge bracket” investment banks stood astride the globe virtually dictating the terms of engagement of international finance  managing deals, pronouncing companies (or countries) investment-worthy or not, and dispensing advice that companies (and countries) ignored at their peril.

articles.headline: Alternative Energy Suddenly Faces Headwinds
articles.snippet: Renewable energy technologies are facing big challenges because of the credit freeze and plunge in oil and natural gas prices.
articles.abstract: Renewable energy technologies are facing big challenges because of the credit freeze and plunge in oil and natural gas prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  For all the support that the presidential candidates are expressing for renewable energy, alternative energies like wind and solar are facing big new challenges because of the credit freeze and the plunge in oil and natural gas prices.

articles.headline: In Hollywood, the Wall St. Plots Will Thicken
articles.snippet: The entertainment industry is grappling with how movies and television should address the economic crisis.
articles.abstract: The entertainment industry is grappling with how movies and television should address the economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Just a few months ago, Lifetime Television started adapting the Candace Bushnell novel “Trading Up” into a movie, figuring an aspirational story about the entitled rich and their limousine culture nailed the cultural moment.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Said to Be Urging New Mergers in Banking
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department reportedly hopes to steer some of the $250 billion rescue to banks willing to buy rivals.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department reportedly hopes to steer some of the $250 billion rescue to banks willing to buy rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a step that could accelerate a shakeout of the nation’s banks, the Treasury Department hopes to spur a new round of mergers by steering some of the money in its $250 billion rescue package to banks that are willing to buy weaker rivals, according to government officials.

articles.headline: 3 Oil-Rich Countries Face a Reckoning
articles.snippet: Falling oil prices are raising questions about whether Venezuela, Iran and Russia can sustain their ambitions.
articles.abstract: Falling oil prices are raising questions about whether Venezuela, Iran and Russia can sustain their ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — As the price of oil roared to ever higher levels in recent years, the leaders of Venezuela, Iran and Russia muscled their way onto the world stage, using checkbook diplomacy and, on occasion, intimidation.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Michael Slackman and Clifford J. Levy

articles.headline: One Day Doesn’t Make a Trend
articles.snippet: Need a mortgage? An auto loan? If you are a business or consumer, it’s almost as hard to get a loan this week as it was last.
articles.abstract: Need a mortgage? An auto loan? If you are a business or consumer, it’s almost as hard to get a loan this week as it was last.
articles.lead_paragraph: The banks aren’t lending. And despite what you have heard, they probably won’t start just yet.

articles.headline: In Fine Print, a Proliferation of Large Donors
articles.snippet: The candidates have benefited from large donors who give tens of thousands of dollars to fund-raising committees.
articles.abstract: The candidates have benefited from large donors who give tens of thousands of dollars to fund-raising committees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Much of the attention on the record amounts of money coursing through the presidential race this year, including in Senator Barack Obama’s announcement on Sunday of his $150 million fund-raising haul in September, has focused on the explosion of small donors.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: A Robot Network Seeks to Enlist Your Computer
articles.snippet: Programs take over PCs remotely and wire them into “botnets,” which help send the majority of e-mail spam, steal financial information and install malicious software.
articles.abstract: Programs take over PCs remotely and wire them into “botnets,” which help send the majority of e-mail spam, steal financial information and install malicious software.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.  In a windowless room on Microsoft’s campus here, T. J. Campana, a cybercrime investigator, connects an unprotected computer running an early version of Windows XP to the Internet. In about 30 seconds the computer is “owned.”

articles.headline: More Alzheimer’s Risk for Hispanics, Studies Find
articles.snippet: A significant number of Hispanics appear to be getting Alzheimer’s earlier, according to recent studies.
articles.abstract: A significant number of Hispanics appear to be getting Alzheimer’s earlier, according to recent studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  Antonio Vasquez was just 60 when Alzheimer’s disease derailed him.

articles.headline: In Sour Economy, Some Scale Back on Medications
articles.snippet: As people respond to hard times by juggling the cost of necessities, drugs sometimes have to wait.
articles.abstract: As people respond to hard times by juggling the cost of necessities, drugs sometimes have to wait.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in at least a decade, the nation’s consumers are trying to get by on fewer prescription drugs.

articles.headline: Investor Sheds a Major Stake in Ford
articles.snippet: The move by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian is a stinging no-confidence vote in America’s auto industry.
articles.abstract: The move by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian is a stinging no-confidence vote in America’s auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  One of the biggest boosters of the American auto industry said Tuesday that he was bailing out of his large stake in the Ford Motor Company  a stinging no-confidence vote that raised the anxiety level in this city over the deepening troubles of the Big Three car companies.

articles.headline: Fed Adds to Its Efforts to Aid Credit Markets
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said it would provide financing to shore up money-market mutual funds.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said it would provide financing to shore up money-market mutual funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Americans have considered money-market mutual funds as safe as bank accounts. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve pledged $540 billion to make sure they really are.
